articles.headline: No More 99 Cent Pizza: Why Washington Is Getting Worried About Inflation
articles.snippet: Price gains have moved up sharply for months, but the fact that the trend is lasting and broadening has newly put policymakers on red alert.
articles.abstract: Price gains have moved up sharply for months, but the fact that the trend is lasting and broadening has newly put policymakers on red alert.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aquan Brunson, 45 and from Brooklyn, used to buy three slices of cheese pizza from 99 Cents Pizza of Utica for lunch each day. But about three months ago, inflation ate away that third slice. The shop has pasted over its old sign to alert customers that it is now “$1.50 Hot Pizza.”

articles.headline: Starbucks workers at a Buffalo store unionize in a big symbolic win for labor.
articles.snippet: The coffee chain’s executives sought to persuade workers to reject the union in an election campaign that began in late August. Workers at a second store voted not to unionize and the result at a third outlet was not clear.
articles.abstract: The coffee chain’s executives sought to persuade workers to reject the union in an election campaign that began in late August. Workers at a second store voted not to unionize and the result at a third outlet was not clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employees at a Buffalo-area Starbucks store have voted to form a union, making it the only one of the nearly 9,000 company-owned stores in the United States to be organized and notching an important symbolic victory for labor at a time when workers across the country are expressing frustration with wages and working conditions.

articles.headline: Appeals Court Rejects Trump’s Bid to Shield Material From Jan. 6 Inquiry
articles.snippet: A three-judge panel held that Congress’s oversight powers, backed by President Biden’s decision not to invoke executive privilege over the material, outweighed Mr. Trump’s residual secrecy powers.
articles.abstract: A three-judge panel held that Congress’s oversight powers, backed by President Biden’s decision not to invoke executive privilege over the material, outweighed Mr. Trump’s residual secrecy powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled on Thursday that Congress is entitled to see White House records related to the Capitol attack on Jan. 6, rejecting former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he still has the power to keep the material secret.

articles.headline: Omicron Brings New Round of Foreboding for British Businesses
articles.snippet: “None of it’s going to be good,” an economist warns as people are likely to retreat from some aspects of social life as Covid measures tighten.
articles.abstract: “None of it’s going to be good,” an economist warns as people are likely to retreat from some aspects of social life as Covid measures tighten.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Thursday morning, a group of 50 called to cancel their holiday party booked for that evening at Luc’s Brasserie, a French restaurant in the financial district of Britain’s capital. That same morning, a group of 21 canceled their party too, also for Thursday night.

articles.headline: Consumer Prices Rose at Fastest Pace Since 1982, Pressuring Washington
articles.snippet: The Consumer Price Index is rising sharply, a concern for Washington policymakers and a sign of the rising costs facing American households.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Price Index is rising sharply, a concern for Washington policymakers and a sign of the rising costs facing American households.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prices are rising at the fastest clip in nearly 40 years, fresh data released on Friday showed, as supply chain disruptions, rapid consumer demand and rising housing costs fuel an inflationary burst.

articles.headline: Turkey’s President Follows His Own Advice Even as Economy Slips
articles.snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is increasingly isolated as he clings to an economic prescription that few endorse but that he believes will bear results before elections.
articles.abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is increasingly isolated as he clings to an economic prescription that few endorse but that he believes will bear results before elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan sat for an interview on national television late last month, apparently seeking to calm nerves about Turkey’s weakening currency and galloping inflation. But the reaction has been anything but calm.

articles.headline: In Texas, a Battle Over What Can Be Taught, and What Books Can Be Read
articles.snippet: A new state law constricts teachers when it comes to race and history. And a politician is questioning why 850 titles are on library shelves. The result: “A lot of our teachers are petrified.”
articles.abstract: A new state law constricts teachers when it comes to race and history. And a politician is questioning why 850 titles are on library shelves. The result: “A lot of our teachers are petrified.”
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Latest Innovation: Troll Philanthropy
articles.snippet: Some very wealthy people give their money away in an attempt to burnish their reputations. Not the Tesla C.E.O.
articles.abstract: Some very wealthy people give their money away in an attempt to burnish their reputations. Not the Tesla C.E.O.
articles.lead_paragraph: The richest people on earth typically devote a share of their vast resources to charity. That is the bargain and the expectation, anyway.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Allows Challenge to Texas Abortion Law but Leaves It in Effect
articles.snippet: The law, which bans most abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, was drafted to evade review in federal court and has been in effect since September.
articles.abstract: The law, which bans most abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, was drafted to evade review in federal court and has been in effect since September.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that abortion providers in Texas can challenge a state law banning most abortions after six weeks, allowing them to sue at least some state officials in federal court despite the procedural hurdles imposed by the law’s unusual structure.
